creator: vnicolici@zapp.ro
text:
The properties should not be immutable.

The "property" task and other tasks that set properties should support 
a "overwrite" attribute with a default of "false".

Sample usage:

<property name="list-target" value="clean" overwrite="true" />

IMHO the current behaviour causes more problems than benefits.

I'm writing ANT scripts since 2004, and I still can't "get used", to this 
extremely annoying behaviour.

Just imagine how quickly the Java programming language would become extinct if 
the variables would become immutable after initialization.

creator: stevel@apache.org
text:
wontfix. Notice how they are called properties, not variables.

1. Is a core design feature which is designed to make it easy for calling ant
tasks and build.properties files to override aspects of nested tasks.

2. 
>Just imagine how quickly the Java programming language would become extinct if 
> the variables would become immutable after initialization. 

Lisp, scheme, ML, Prolog, XSL: all have immutable bindings, bindings that some
of the languages actually call "variables". 

3. If you need it, there is the ant-contrib <var> task

creator: phil.weighill-smith@volantis.com
text:
(In reply to comment #0)

> Just imagine how quickly the Java programming language would become extinct if 
> the variables would become immutable after initialization.

Take a look at "final", and look at String, Integer etc. too. This hasn't killed
Java. And as stated in the other response, properties are not variables.

creator: vnicolici@zapp.ro
text:
(In reply to comment #2)
Yes, and I'm sure that all the Java code in the core ANT implementation uses 
only final "variables", fields, parameters, methods and classes.

Java gives freedom to the developer. ANT takes it away.

(In reply to comment #1)
Thanks for directing me to the <var> task.
I will unset the properties with <var name="xxx" unset="true" /> before 
setting them to achieve the desired behaviour. It's ugly, but works.
